Award.AbstractNarration: The Koniag Alutiiq Orthography project will compile and complete existing, unpublished research to develop a stable, standardized orthography system for Kodiak Alutiiq. The PI, Dr. April Counceller of the Alutiiq Museum and University of Alaska - Kodiak College, will work with renowned Alutiiq Linguist Jeff Leer, who is recently retired from the Alaska Native Language Center at UAF. Counceller will compile Leer's previous research notes and articles on the Alutiiq writing system, collect new data from the few remaining fluent speakers (less than 50, all elderly and scattered throughout Alaska), and create a writing system book that will be accessible to heritage speakers. This data will be of great interest to language scholars developing orthographies for endangered languages and for comparative linguistics. In addition the project will create materials that this will assist in the preservation of the Alutiiq language for future heritage speakers. The project PI correctly states that this project is appropriate for RAPID funding because many factors have converged to make this project successful and timely: 1) the availability and willingness of Dr. Leer to participate; 2) the waning availability of a few fluent first-language speakers; 3) The Alaska Native Corporation, Chugachmiut's willingness to support Dr. Counceller through sharing of similar-dialect materials, and 4) the urgent need in the community for the orthography in order to produce language revitalization texts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Koniag Alutiiq (EMS) Orthography Project resulted in a published book on the writing system for a severely threatened Alaska Native dialect. This effort addressed a timely need for this orthographic resource before the final generation of first language speakers becomes unavailable.

Project PI April Counceller, Ph.D. compiled existing, unpublished research by Jeff Leer, Ph.D along with new data from fluent speakers to publish a standardized writing system guide for Kodiak Alutiiq.  Drs. Counceller and Leer developed a user-friendly guide to the Alutiiq writing system that teaches Kodiak Alutiiq alphabet, spelling, orthographical patterns and rules. Building on a previous partial manuscript for a related dialect developed by Chugachmiut, Inc., the Kodiak Alutiiq Orthography Project connected uniquely available people and resources in order to make available a book suitable for lay language learners and linguistic scholars alike.

Recent increases in Alutiiq language documentation, education, and revitalization, led to a surge in the creation of printed materials in Alutiiq, but there are few considered literate in the language – even among those developing documentation and teaching materials. This resource fills that critical need. Participation by Alutiiq speakers, and strong collaborative relationships between project partners helped ensure this project's success.

The Kodiak Alutiiq Orthography Project addressed an identified gap in academic research on Koniag Alutiiq, finalizing decades of work in the development of a stable orthography. The project published an easily-accessed reference text based on all available information on the Alutiiq writing system that can be utilized by scholars of Alutiiq and other Esk-Aleut languages. The book is available for free from the Alutiiq Museum and the Alaska Native Language Center, or by download form the Museum's website (www.alutiiqmuseum.org/files/Language/Orthography/OrthographyBook.pdf).

Research for the Kodiak Alutiiq Orthography Project drew from both academic and community understandings of Alutiiq. Creating a resource relevant to academic and lay audiences took foresight, but expanded the audience and value of the end-result.  Importantly, this project included oversight by the Alutiiq community, and a human subjects protocol based on the Alaska Federation of Natives (AFN) Guidelines for Research. The project’s publication and dissemination efforts serve as a model of community-driven research methods, and the value of collaborative relationships between indigenous research organizations, academic institutions, and threatened language groups.
